intro: Abutilon propinquum, commonly known as the velvetleaf abutilon, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is characterized by its fuzzy, velvety leaves and showy, lantern-shaped flowers that range in color from yellow to orange. The plant typically grows as an annual or perennial shrub, reaching heights of up to 2 meters. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is often found in disturbed soils or along roadsides. Its botanical features make it a popular choice for ornamental gardening due to its attractive appearance and adaptability.

It is found in the northeastern regions of the country, including the states of Pará, Maranhão, and Piauí. This plant thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in moist, shaded areas within dense forests. It is commonly associated with riverbanks and lowland forests, where it benefits from high humidity and nutrient-rich soils. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and localized species within its native range.
